projects.name: DJ Tools
projects.description: DJ Tools started out as a set of scripts used to sync audio files to the cloud so I could share tracks with my friends. It's since grown into a Python library with many features for streamlining the processes around collecting, curating, and sharing a music collection.

projects.name: Liquidemocracy
projects.description: This is my most ambitious project of which I'm very fond of. Currently, it exists only in requirements analysis and design form, but is is also the focus of my senior project. By the end of spring 2018, this application will be ready for deployment. Liquidemocracy is a policy information tool that's designed to provide feedback to representatives whose constitutes utilize the application. The premise is that policy should be generated in a grass-roots manner by escalating concerning issues through legislation definition and then polling. A social recommendation system suggests friends to whom a particular user may want to delegate votes for a particular issue or category of issues to and filters issues such that the user is only presented with the most interesting and relevant policy topics. Show less

projects.name: IEEE Smart World NVIDIA AI City Challenge 2017
projects.description: Our competition team trained two independent deep learning models to process image and video data. The first model used the Darknet framework's YOLO model architecture with Darknet19_448 pre-trained convolutional weights to localize bounding boxes around detected objects and classify them as one of 14 classes. The second model used the Keras framework with VGG-16 pre-trained convolutional weights and attempted to predict vehicle counts without any network architectural consideration for region proposals (as localization is standard practice in detecting individual objects in a single image). Our team ranked 2nd place in the competition with a mean-average precision (mAP) score ranging from 0.38 - 0.47 (depending on which dataset was used for testing). Our localization scores were calculated as the intersection over union (IOU) between predicted and true bounding boxes and ranged from 0.67 - 0.89. Show less

projects.name: QLoop
projects.description: QLoop is a web app for conveniently distributing the blessing (or burden) of choosing the next song. It is a NodeJS project utilizing node-youtube-dl, a module for downloading youtube videos, in order to extract .ogg files as audio resources for clients. Users queue songs in a running playlist to be enjoyed publicly or privately. Creators of playlists can invite friends via email as an alternative to having them search for the playlist manually. Upon joining, users select whether or not their device should play the songs queued in addition to the playlist creator's device. QLoop_v2 is a rekindling of the original project but redesigned to use a different technology stack including React and Flask. Show less

projects.name: Diabetic Retinopathy
projects.description: This is an analysis of several classification models I built to classify images of retinas as belonging to either healthy individuals or individuals belonging to one of four classes corresponding to increasingly severe diabetes. The methods and models used include principle component analysis (PCA / dimensionality reduction), a convolutional neural network (TensorFlow), XGBoost (a gradient boosting tree algorithm), and scikit-learn implementations of K-nearest neighbors and support vector machine classifiers. Show less

projects.name: Procedural Learning Simulator
projects.description: This project is a tool for dynamically constructing simulations of procedural learning in acetylcholine based tonically active networks (TAN). The aim of this project was to abstract the development process of these experiments and incorporate the simulation design and graphing of the results in one graphic user interface (GUI) environment. This project utilizes Python's PySide for GUI development and matplotlib for the graphing utilities. The simulation template C files were abstracted from code developed by Dr. Matthew Crossley and the researchers at Richard Ivry's Cognitive Action Lab at UC Berkeley. Show less

publications.title: Robust Classification of City Roadway Objects for  Traffic Related Applications
publications.description: As part of the IEEE SmartWorld Conference 2017, our team participated in the AI City Challenge for which we developed two neural network models. Using the DarkNet and Keras frameworks, we constructed models for localizing and classifying objects and also for predicting traffic density in traffic camera footage. Our submitted model achieved an overall mean average precision score that placed us in second for the competition.

publications.title: Scalability and distribution of collaborative recommenders
publications.description: "Scalability and distribution of collaborative recommenders" is chapter 10 of the yet to be published book "Collaborative Recommendations: Algorithms, Practical Challenges and Applications". My role in this publication was to run experiments on a computing cluster to produce results and figures for the computing the K-nearest neighbor graphs for the MovieLens dataset.

publications.title: No-FAT: Architectural Support for Low Overhead Memory Safety Checks
publications.description: Memory safety continues to be a significant software reliability and security problem, and low overhead and low complexity hardware solutions have eluded computer designers. In this paper, we explore a pathway to deployable memory safety defenses. Our technique builds on a recent trend in software: the usage of binning memory allocators. We observe that if memory allocation sizes (e.g., malloc sizes) are made an architectural feature, then it is possible to overcome many of the thorny issues with traditional approaches to memory safety such as compatibility with unsecured software and significant performance degradation. We show that our architecture, No-FAT, incurs an overhead of 8% on SPEC CPU2017 benchmarks, and our VLSI measurements show low power and area overheads. Finally, as No-FAT’s hardware is aware of the memory allocation sizes, it effectively mitigates certain speculative attacks (e.g., SpectreV1) with no additional cost. When our solution is used for pre-deployment fuzz testing it can improve fuzz testing bandwidth by an order of magnitude compared to state-of-the-art approaches. Show less

“I had the privilege of working with Gil on a challenging AgriTech project. As a deep learning consultant, Gil was absolutely instrumental in our success. 
Gil provided us with not just advice, but also continuously reviewing our progress. His mentorship was key in helping us to create a working proof-of-concept model. Gil's understanding of deep learning is impressive, and his ability to mentor and guide is unparalleled. I confidently recommend Gil to any team looking for expertise and guidance in deep learning. With him on your side, you're set up for success.”

“Gil eats, drinks and breathes computer vision. For him this is not just work, it’s his hobby as well. As such, Gil is always up to date with everything that happens in the academic world as well as within the community. 
Even though he is such an avid computer vision researcher, when he needs to productise his code, you can count on him to do it.

If you are looking for a Computer Vision or Deep Learning expert, don’t think twice.
”

publications.title: Connecting Supervised and Unsupervised Sentence Embeddings
publications.description: Representing sentences as numerical vectors while capturing their semantic context is an important and useful intermediate step in natural language processing. Representations that are both general and discriminative can serve as a tool for tackling various NLP tasks. While common sentence representation methods are unsupervised in nature, recently, an approach for learning universal sentence representation in a supervised setting was presented in (Conneau et al., 2017). We argue that although promising results were obtained, an improvement can be reached by adding various unsupervised constraints that are motivated by auto-encoders and by language models. We show that by adding such constraints, superior sentence embeddings can be achieved. We compare our method with the original implementation and show improvements in several tasks. Show less

publications.title: A Method for Segmentation, Matching and Alignment of Dead Sea Scrolls
publications.description: Talk at WACV: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4jNTJkK37pc The Dead Sea Scrolls are of great historical significance. Lamentably, in the decades since their discovery, many fragments have deteriorated. Fortunately, low-resolution grayscale infrared images of the Palestinian Archaeological Museum plates holding the scrolls in their discovered state are extant, along with recent high-quality multispectral images by the Israel Antiquities Authority. However, the necessary task of identifying each fragment in the new images on the old plates is tedious and time consuming to perform manually, and is often problematic when fragments have been moved from the original plate. We describe an automated system that segments the new and old images of fragments from the background on which they were imaged, finds their matches on the old plates and aligns and superimposes them. To this end, we developed a deep-learning based segmentation method and a cascade approach for template matching, based on scale, shape analysis and dense matching Show less

publications.title: Temporal Tessellation for Video Annotation and Summarization
publications.description: We present a general approach for various video understanding tasks. We have tested our method for video captioning on the LSMDC'16 benchmark, video summarization on the SumMe and TVSum benchmarks, Temporal Action Detection on the Thumos2014 benchmark, achieving state of the art results on all three tasks. Code: https://github.com/dot27/temporal-tessellation

publications.title: The CUDA LATCH Binary Descriptor: Because Sometimes Faster Means Better
publications.description: This paper presents a CUDA port for the recent Learned Arrangement of Three Patches (LATCH) binary descriptors to the GPU platform. The design of LATCH makes it well suited for GPU processing. Owing to its small size and binary nature, the GPU can further be used to efficiently match LATCH features. Taken together, this leads to breakneck descriptor extraction and matching speeds. We use our proposed CUDA LATCH (CLATCH) to recover structure from motion (SfM), comparing 3D reconstructions and speed using different representations. Our results show that CLATCH provides high quality 3D reconstructions at fractions of the time required by other representations, with little, if any, loss of reconstruction quality. Show less

publications.title: LATCH: Learned Arrangements of Three Patch Codes
publications.description: We present a novel means of describing local image appearances using binary strings, namely - the Learned Arrangements of Three Patch Codes descriptors, or LATCH. In order to provide more robustness, we propose a novel means of comparing triplets of pixel patches. Our resulting LATCH representation is rigorously compared to state-of-the-art binary descriptors and shown to provide far better performance for similar computation and space requirements. We have also integrated our C++ implementation of the LATCH descriptor to OpenCV3.0. Note: Winner of CVPR15 OpenCV challenge. Show less

publications.title: Emotion Recognition in the Wild via Convolutional Neural Networks and Mapped Binary Patterns
publications.description: We present a novel method for classifying emotions from static facial images. We propose novel transformations of image intensities to 3D spaces based on Local Binary Patterns, designed to be invariant to monotonic photometric transformations. These are applied to CASIA Webface images which are then used to train an ensemble of multiple architecture Convolutional Neural networks on multiple representations. Each model is then fine-tuned with limited emotion labeled training data to obtain final classification models. Show less

publications.title: Age and Gender Classification using Convolutional Neural Networks
publications.description: In this paper we show that by learning representations through the use of deep-convolutional neural networks (CNN), a significant increase in performance can be obtained on these tasks. To this end, we propose a simple convolutional net architecture that can be used even when the amount of learning data is limited. We evaluate our method on the recent Adience benchmark for age and gender estimation and show it to dramatically outperform current state-of-the-art methods..
